title: How to Recognize Fake Instagram Accounts

steps.title: A profile without an identifying photo probably isn't real.
steps.content: A profile without an identifying photo probably isn't real. A legit account would want people to know who they are so their friends and family members can find them. [1] X Research source This could also be a friend that just hasn’t had time to add a profile pic, but it’s unlikely.

steps.title: Legitimate Instagram accounts will almost always have a few followers.
steps.content: Legitimate Instagram accounts will almost always have a few followers. If the account hasn’t followed anyone or doesn’t have any followers, it’s most likely fake. [2] X Research source Bots usually use accounts like these to promote spam links in their bios. If you come across a profile like this, don’t click any links.

steps.title: Accounts without any posts are most likely trying to scam you.
steps.content: Accounts without any posts are most likely trying to scam you. If you come across an account that hasn’t posted anything yet, it’s probably a bot. [3] X Research source Even if the profile is private, you can check their post number by looking at the top of their profile. You should also look out for accounts that used to post a lot but don’t anymore. If they’ve been inactive for a while, they could be fake.

steps.title: A fake account might be trying to get you to follow them back.
steps.content: A fake account might be trying to get you to follow them back. If they comment “great post!” or “nice shot!” on a lot of your pictures in rapid succession, they might be fake. [4] X Research source However, this could also be an influencer trying to gain a new follower. If you check out their profile and don’t see any other red flags, they’re probably a real person.

steps.title: Impersonation is a surefire way to spot a fake account.
steps.content: Impersonation is a surefire way to spot a fake account. You can run their images through a reverse Google search ; if the photos pop up somewhere else, it likely means the account is fake. [5] X Research source If you see an account using photos from you or someone else, you can report them on the app or by visiting https://help.instagram.com/contact/636276399721841 .

steps.title: Fake accounts try to up their followers by following a lot of people.
steps.content: Fake accounts try to up their followers by following a lot of people. If you notice a huge discrepancy between their following number and their followers, there’s a chance that their account is fake. [6] X Research source This isn’t always the case, since some real accounts use the same tactic to up their followers, too. However, it can be a good jumping off point to start with.

steps.title: Instagram accounts that aren’t well established have a higher chance of being fake.
steps.content: Instagram accounts that aren’t well established have a higher chance of being fake. Scroll down to the bottom of the profile and check the date of the first post. If it’s not more than a few days old, there’s a good chance the account is fake. [7] X Research source If the account is private, you won’t be able to scroll and see their posts until they accept your following request. If the account has 0 posts, that’s a good indication that they’re fake, too.

steps.title: Fake or purchased followers often indicate a fake account.
steps.content: Fake or purchased followers often indicate a fake account. If their following is in the thousands but they only get a few likes or comments per post, they may have a fake profile. [8] X Research source This could also indicate a real person using fake followers to up their numbers. You can also check out their followers to see if they look real or not. If a lot of their followers are inactive, don’t have profile photos, or have super generic names, it’s a good indication that the followers are fake (so the account might be too).

steps.title: These fake accounts are easy to spot within a few seconds.
steps.content: These fake accounts are easy to spot within a few seconds. If all the photos on their account are of different people (usually attractive women who might look similar but not identical), the account is fake. [9] X Research source Accounts like these are usually spam accounts trying to get people to click the links in their bios.

steps.title: Scam accounts will often offer luxury goods at a steep discount.
steps.content: Scam accounts will often offer luxury goods at a steep discount. If a profile ever wants you to click a link for a discounted item, it’s most likely fake. [10] X Trustworthy Source Federal Trade Commission Website with up-to-date information for consumers from the Federal Trade Commisson Go to source The most common account like this is one selling discounted Ray Bans. You might also see accounts like these on Twitter and Facebook . Never give your credit card info to an Instagram account.
